dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2015, the Sustainable Development Goals made ending AIDS a priority, but it was never actually achieved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty fifteen, the Sustainable Development Goals made ending A I D S a priority, but it was never actually achieved.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Progress was swift and when the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) succeeded the MDGs in 2015, ending AIDS was no longer a standalone goal. Rather, further progress had become one of 169 targets that the SDGs are supposed to achieve by 2030.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the text mentions that it became a standalone goal, which is uh, kind of ironic given how little progress followed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the text mentions that it became a standalone goal, which is uh, kind of ironic given how little progress followed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Progress was swift and when the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) succeeded the MDGs in 2015, ending AIDS was no longer a standalone goal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there's this claim that biomedical responses are universally agreed upon and perfectly implemented, which just feels... disconnected from reality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then there's this claim that biomedical responses are universally agreed upon and perfectly implemented, which just feels... disconnected from reality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biomedical responses are vital to disease control, but if people cannot access medicine or preventive services, even the best-designed initiatives will fail. Whats more, the obstacles to treatment often have nothing to do with health care, but rather, are tied to political, economic, and social marginalization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, if that were true, why would millions of people still be getting zero support after testing positive?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, if that were true, why would millions of people still be getting zero support after testing positive?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nonetheless, millions of people still do not know their HIV status or cannot get the support they need when they test positive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the part about LGBT communities in Tanzania—it says they were "eradicated," which is just horrifying, and it totally destroyed HIV prevention there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the part about L G B T communities in Tanzania-it says they were eradicated, which is just horrifying, and it totally destroyed H I V prevention there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, just last month in Tanzania, hundreds of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) people were forced into hiding after a city official in Dar es Salaam warned that a taskforce was being created to identify and punish gay people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a stark example of how human rights issues are completely intertwined with public health, but the article suggests those links are being ignored on purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a stark example of how human rights issues are completely intertwined with public health, but the article suggests those links are being ignored on purpose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Those on the frontlines of the AIDS response have always recognized that the disease cannot be overcome in isolation; rather, it must be addressed through an interconnected set of social, cultural, economic, and legal challenges. That is why activists have spent years working to repeal discriminatory laws, develop education programs to improve sexual and reproductive health, and build networks of supporters who understand that HIV does not discriminate by nationality, sexuality, or economic status.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and then it points out that governments have stopped implementing SDGs in areas like social protection and gender-based violence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and then it points out that governments have stopped implementing SDGs in areas like social protection and gender-based violence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When governments work to implement the SDGs in areas like social protection, food security, and gender-based violence, HIV responses must also be part of their plans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which are, like, huge drivers of the epidemic! It's almost as if they're trying to make things worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which are, like, huge drivers of the epidemic! It's almost as if they're trying to make things worse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Christine Stegling from the International HIV/AIDS Alliance is cited at the end, which adds weight to how serious these claims are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Christine Stegling from the International H I V/A I D S Alliance is cited at the end, which adds weight to how serious these claims are.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Christine Stegling is Executive Director of the International HIV/AIDS Alliance Project Syndicate 1995-2018

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the tone of the piece is so sarcastic—like when it says "testing positive is a cause for celebration." You can tell the author is furious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the tone of the piece is so sarcastic-like when it says testing positive is a cause for celebration. You can tell the author is furious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, in many parts of the world, HIV is now considered a chronic disease manageable with medication and lifestyle changes; that fact alone is worthy of celebration.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's pointing out this massive gap between the perceived victory over AIDS and the grim reality on the ground.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's pointing out this massive gap between the perceived victory over A I D S and the grim reality on the ground.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the transition from a goal to a target, combined with steep declines in AIDS-related deaths, has lulled us into a false sense of accomplishment. Today, many argue that AIDS is nearing its end.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And that idea that we should eliminate any link between HIV strategies and poverty or education? That's basically guaranteeing failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that idea that we should eliminate any link between H I V strategies and poverty or education? That's basically guaranteeing failure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's like advocating for ignoring all the root causes and then acting surprised when the problem doesn't go away.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's like advocating for ignoring all the root causes and then acting surprised when the problem doesn't go away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it reads like a wake-up call disguised as a victory lap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it reads like a wake-up call disguised as a victory lap.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2015, the Sustainable Development Goals made ending AIDS a priority, but it was never actually achieved.
HostB: Right, and the text mentions that it became a standalone goal, which is uh, kind of ironic given how little progress followed.
HostA: Exactly. And then there's this claim that biomedical responses are universally agreed upon and perfectly implemented, which just feels... disconnected from reality.
HostB: Yeah, like, if that were true, why would millions of people still be getting zero support after testing positive?
HostA: And the part about LGBT communities in Tanzania—it says they were "eradicated," which is just horrifying, and it totally destroyed HIV prevention there.
HostB: It’s such a stark example of how human rights issues are completely intertwined with public health, but the article suggests those links are being ignored on purpose.
HostA: Mhm, and then it points out that governments have stopped implementing SDGs in areas like social protection and gender-based violence.
HostB: Which are, like, huge drivers of the epidemic! It’s almost as if they’re trying to make things worse.
HostA: And Christine Stegling from the International HIV/AIDS Alliance is cited at the end, which adds weight to how serious these claims are.
HostB: But the tone of the piece is so sarcastic—like when it says "testing positive is a cause for celebration." You can tell the author is furious.
HostA: For sure. It’s pointing out this massive gap between the perceived victory over AIDS and the grim reality on the ground.
HostB: And that idea that we should eliminate any link between HIV strategies and poverty or education? That’s basically guaranteeing failure.
HostA: Yeah, it’s like advocating for ignoring all the root causes and then acting surprised when the problem doesn’t go away.
HostB: Honestly, it reads like a wake-up call disguised as a victory lap.
